name: 1,3-Butadiene

energies.comment: Conjugated system (alternating double bonds) but acyclic. Shows +38 kJ/mol conjugation stabilization - STRONGER than previously claimed but still MUCH less than benzene's +148 kJ/mol (benzene/butadiene = 3.9× amplification). Calculated from NIST: ΔHf = 108.8 ± 0.79 kJ/mol → BDE = (4×716.68 + 6×218.0) - 108.8 = 4066 kJ/mol. Tests: does conjugation require cycles for strong amplification? Answer: Acyclic conjugation exists (+38) but cyclic amplifies by 3.9×. CORRECTED from previous value (4045, +17 kJ/mol) which underestimated by 55% (-21 kJ/mol error).
energies.source: Prosen et al., J. Res. NBS 1951, 46:106-112; NIST Chemistry WebBook
energies.confidence_note: NIST-verified experimental value with tight uncertainty. Acyclic conjugation baseline for comparison to cyclic systems.

notes: Alternating double bonds allow π-electron delocalization
Central C-C bond has partial double-bond character (~1.46 Å)
NIST-verified conjugation: +38 kJ/mol (was incorrectly claimed as ~17)
Acyclic conjugation is STRONGER than initially thought
But still 3.9× less than benzene (+148 kJ/mol) - cycle amplification confirmed
Critical test: is the cycle necessary for strong amplification? Answer: YES
Linear conjugation provides significant stabilization (+38 kJ/mol)
But cyclic topology amplifies this by 3.9× through feedback loops
